Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The buddhist friend asks to discuss a recent sermon they attended.
Story:
I sat in my clinic, reviewing the chart of my next patient—a middle-aged man with a runny nose and mild cough. The symptoms pointed to a common cold, but as a doctor, I knew I had to be thorough. I needed to ask the right questions, order the right tests if necessary, and ensure I didn’t miss anything serious. Just as I was about to call him in, my phone buzzed. It was my close friend from the temple, eager to discuss a sermon on impermanence we’d both heard last night. He wanted to talk now, saying he was struggling to understand its meaning and needed my perspective as a fellow Buddhist.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My patient was waiting, expecting my full attention and expertise. My friend, too, was reaching out, hoping for spiritual guidance and companionship. I could sense the tension rising in my chest—my duty to heal and my commitment to spiritual reflection pulling me in opposite directions. I stared at the phone, then at the patient’s file, caught in the silent struggle between my roles, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
